newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong hopeful unveils glowing vision of future.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong hopeful unveils glowing vision of future.

text.p: A billionaire businessman vying to lead Hong Kong when the British depart next year mapped out a vision on Tuesday of a glowing future for a community proud to be Chinese.
"I believe we should be proud of being Chinese," shipping magnate Tung Chee-hwa told a Hong Kong Management Association dinner.
But Tung steered clear of many of the issues preoccupying the British colony with just 252 days to go before the territory returns to Chinese rule.
Long considered a frontrunner to be the territory's first Chief Executive, Tung formally declared his leadership intentions last Friday.
Tung stressed the need for strength to resist political pressure and also the need to be flexible.
"What is the thing the Chief Executive needs to do? Protecting Hong Kong interests. Protecting Hong Kong interests," Tung said.
"Compromise is not a weakness," he added in a message apparently aimed at both the Hong Kong democratic lobby and Beijing. "The best way to resolve differences in the long-run is through compromise."
Tung also promised to work with the controversial provisional legislature China plans to establish to replace Hong Kong's elected chamber.
Hong Kong's vocal pro-democracy lobby and outgoing British administration are united in their opposition to China's plan to quash the existing legislature.

Hong Kong reverts to China at midnight on June 30 next year under the terms of a 1984 Sino-British treaty in which the tiny territory of just six million people was promised it could maintain its freedoms and capitalist way of life intact.
Tung sidestepped the thorny issue of Chinese dissidents. "You place too much emphasis on this question," he told reporters after the dinner address.
Hours before Tung stood up to deliver his policy platform, what had been a three-way race intensified when a former Appeal Court judge threw his hat into the ring.
Simon Li's entry into the leadership race broadens what had been a contest between two business titans and a top judge.
Tung heads one of Hong Kong's most prominent shipping empires, while businessman Peter Woo is the son-in-law of late shipping tsar Sir Y.K. Pao.
The Pao and Tung families have long been rivals in Hong Kong business circles.
The third candidate, outgoing Chief Justice Sir Ti Liang Yang, had, until Li joined the fray, been regarded as the compromise candidate free of business ties and alliances.
Hong Kong's first post-colonial leader will be selected by a 400-strong electoral college chosen in turn by a China-appointed committee and not returned by universal suffrage.
